question: Skin pigmentation & Icthyosis like side effects are seen in
exp: Ichthyosis - Fish like scaling (d/t severe dryness in patient) - Causing skin to break Two types - Congenital Acquired I. vulgaris - Autosomal Dominant, MC type Deficiency - Filaggrin Involves Extensors Leprosy - Involvement of ANS No sweating - dry skin X linked ichthyosis - X-linked Recessive defect with steroid sulphatase Extensor + Flexors involvement Clofazimine - Causes darkening and dryness of skin Lamellar ichthyosis - Autosomal Recessive Defect with Transglutaminase Whole body involvement When infant born is covered with Membrane called collodion membrane then baby k/a collodion baby. Most severe type Ichthyosis - Harlequin ichthyosis - Autosomal Recessive- Due to ABCA-12 gene defect

question: Which of the following sign is present in Subungual melanoma?
exp: Hutchinson's sign: Periungual extension of brown-black pigmentation from longitudinal melanonychia onto the proximal and lateral nail folds, is an impoant indicator of subungual melanoma. Fitzpatrick's sign: Also called as Dimple sign present in dermatofibroma. Pastia's sign: in streptococcal scarlet fever. Frank's sign-Frank's sign is a diagonal crease inthe ear lobeextending from the tragus across the lobule to the rear edge of the auricle. Frank's sign is indicative ofcardiovascular diseaseand/or diabetes. Hutchinson's sign- If there is skin lesions at the tip, side, or root of the nose there are strong chances of ocular inflammation and corneal denervation in HZO.

question: Lines of Blaschko's are related to:
exp: Lines of Blaschko's are related to keratinocyte. Blaschko's Lines: The pattern is attributed to the lines of migration and proliferation of epidermal cells during embryogenesis The lines do not correspond to any known nervous, vascular or lymphatic structures, but represent the normal developmental growth pattern of the skin. Generally longitudinally oriented on the limbs and circumferential on the trunk, but not perfectly linear. Implies a mosaic disorder e. g. - Incontinentia pigmenti, -inflammatory linear verrucous epidermal nevus

question: True about incontinenta pigmenti includes the following except:
exp: INCONTINENTIA PIGMENTI X-linked dominant neurocutaneous syndrome with cutaneous, neurologic, ophthalmologic, and dental manifestations. Skin features occur in 4 stages Stage 1 (vesicular) Stage 2 (verrucous) Stage 3 (hyperpigmented) Stage 4 (atrophic/hypopigmented) Ophthalmologic findings Ophthalmologic findings occur in 20-35% of patients, and asymmetric involvement is common. Retinal vaso-occlusive events with resultant ischemia is primary mechanism in ocular pathology Treatment: Family counselling may prevent occurrence of new cases Skin lesions subside in adulthood spontaneously
opd: Ocular involvement is seen in almost 100% cases and is typically unilateral

question: Recurrent erythematous plaques on glans penis in a 21 yrs old sexually active male which heals with residual hyperpigmentation, is suggestive of?
exp: Fixed Drug Eruptions Characterized by one or more sharply demarcated, erythematous lesions, sometimes leading to a blister. Hyperpigmentation results after resolution of the acute inflammation. With rechallenge, the lesion recurs in the same (i. e. fixed) location. Lesions often involve the lips, hands, legs, face, genitalia and oral mucosa and cause burning sensation. Patch testing used to establish etiology.

question: A lady came with complaints of a bluish lesion over left side of forehead and left eye. Shows irregular bluish lesion in left superior conjunctiva and forehead. What is most probable diagnosis?
exp: Nevus of Ota: Unilateral bluish grey colour discolouration. Along ophthalmic and maxillary division of Trigeminal nerve. Naevus of ito- along acromioclavicular nerve (neck). Mongolian spots- Bluish discoloration in infants (MC site is lower back). Becker's nevus- Hyperpimented path with hyperichosis over upper trunk

question: Mode of inheritance of incontinentia pigmenti is:
exp: Incontinentia pigmenti - X-linked dominant Developmental defects of eye, teeth, CNS with cutaneous lesions. Four clinical stages - Inflammatory macules, papules, vesicle. Hyperkeratotic & verrucous lessions Grey-brown pigmentation Atrophic, hypopigmented & depimented - Initially hyperpigmented lesions; as it progresses towards 4th stage, it becomes hypopigmented - Lesions follow the lines of blaschko. X linked dominant diseases-Vit- D resistant rickets (X linked hypophosphataemia)-Rett syndrome-Incontinentia pigmenti-Alpo syndrome-Fragile X syndrome-Goltz syndrome-X linked protoporphyria

question: A newborn had pinkish-blue lesion over upper eyelid. There was no lid edema or eye involvement and the lesion regressed spontaneously at about one year of age. What is the diagnosis?
exp: Salmon Patch (Nevus Simplex) Small, pale, pink, ill-defined, vascular macules on the glabella, eyelids, upper lip, and nuchal area Present as localized vascular ectasia and may become more visible during crying or changes in environmental temperature. Lesions on the face fade and disappear completely, but on the posterior neck and occipital areas often persist. Symmetric lesions on both eyelids & both sides of midline. Po-wine stains are often larger, unilateral, permanent & usually end along the midline.

question: Pigmentation due to increased melanin production but no melanocyte proliferation, is seen in?
exp: Causes of Hyperpigmentation Increased pigment( melanin) production Ephelides (freckles) Cafe au lait macule Post inflammatory hyperpigmentation Proliferation of melanocytes Lentigo Nevus Melanoma

question: Which is the most effective topically applied bleaching agent?
exp: Hydroquinone is most effective topically applied bleaching agent. It bleach freckles and lentigens but not cafe-au-lait spots or pigmented nevi.

question: Kamino bodies are seen in
exp: Kamino bodies are the eosinophilic globules seen in Spitz nevus( it is benign melanocytic nevus, a type of skin lesion, affecting the epidermis and dermis)

question: Ceruloderma is characterised by-
exp: Ceruloderma- Due to defect in migration of melanocyte. Melanocyte derived from neural crest and migrate to stratum basale (epidermis) Defect in migration of melanocytes due to which they remain in dermis Eg. Of Ceruloderma - 1. Mongolian spot 2. Nevus of OTA3. Nevus of ITO Clinical features - Dermis- Blue lesion - Don't become dark under wood's lamp. Blue d/t - Tyndall effect/optical effect i. e. paial scattering of light Most of light reflected back is blue in colour.
opa: Excess melanin in dermis, pigmentation not accentuated under Wood's lamp
opb: Excess melanin in basal and suprabasal layers, pigmentation accentuated under Wood's lamp
opd: Excess melanin in basal and suprabasal layers, pigmentation not accentuated under Wood's lamp
